awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Exploiting the Low/Medium Frequency (LF/MF) Radio Band for Ionospheric Remote Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Number: AGS 1653114
Principal Investigator: Morris Cohen
Institution: Georgia Tech 
Proposal title: CAREER: Exploiting the LF/MF Radio Band for Ionospheric Remote Sensing 

This proposal aims to measure electron density in the 60-100 km altitude range using radio transmissions near 300 kHz. Electron density at these altitudes is perturbed by tropospheric weather (i. e., thunderstorms), and by seismic, geomagnetic, and solar activity. These disturbances affect the propagation of radio waves used for navigation, positioning and communication, but their effects have never been systematically explored. The proposed work is primarily experimental in nature, with the objectives of characterizing and quantifying the detectability of several types of ionospheric disturbances using beacon signals of opportunity. 

The PI will design and build receivers that will detect LF/MF radio waves near 300 kHz transmitted from a network of GPS beacons. A series of observation campaigns is planned at midlatitudes under quiescent conditions and during a solar eclipse, and at high latitudes under quiescent and artificially heated conditions. The proposal also contains three educational components: 1. Material for 1-2 Ph.D. dissertations; 2. An undergraduate level balloon project to make correlative measurements; 3. K-12 instruction and participation via installation of LF/MF receivers in rural area schools.

por.por_cntn:
The uppermost portion of the Earth's atmosphere contains an electrically charged layer known as the ionosphere, which can be thought of as the border zone between Earth and space. Beginning at ~60 km altitude, the sun's radiation rips apart molecules to form this plasma. As an electrically charged layer, the ionosphere affects several forms of communications, including satellite-to-ground, and over-the-horizon ground communications.

The ionosphere in general is highly variable but the lowest part, known as the D-region (60-90 km) is particularly difficult to sense, as it can't be directly and continuously measured by either balloons or satellites. Using radio waves at low frequencies (< 500 kHz) is a promising avenue since that energy reflects from the D-region, so it can be used to probe the D-region continuously.

Low frequencies emerge from three sources: US Navy transmitters between 19 and 50 kHz, US Coast Guard transmitters known as NDGPS between 285 and 315 kHz, and brief pulses from natural lightning.

In this project, we developed methods to use all three of those to remotely monitor the ionosphere.

For the US Navy transmitters, we built on prior work and developed a machine learning algorithm that uses a network of VLF/LF radio receivers, all listening to a small number of known transmitters, to infer the electrical state of the lower ionosphere along any transmitter-receiver path. For the NDGPS signals, we developed a new propagation model and bounded the spatial roughness properties of the lower ionosphere for the first time. However, the NDGPS transmitters were shut down during the project, so further work was hampered. For the lightning-generated signals, we also built on past work but added some tomographic reconstruction to produce 3D map of the electricla state of the ionosphere using a network of receivers listening to the emissions from a constellation of many thunderstorms. We demonstrated this on real data.
